Anscombe’s Quartet


Anscombe's Quartet is a set of four scatterplots that have the same mean, standard deviation, and correlation. However, they all have very distinct and different stories when we visualise them.

Data summaries such as means, standard deviations, and correlations are important - but depending solely on them can be risky. Incredibly different datasets can yield comparable outcomes. 



There is more information on this given here. But, in brief, these simple statistics are not enough to illustrate the data. We need to dig deeper to truly understand the data and patterns within it.

This has been taken a step further to give:


The Datasaurus Dozen



Here we see 12 plots, each with the same mean, standard deviation, and correlations (to 2dp):

  • Same mean and standard deviation for X in all these plots (to 2dp);
  • Same mean and standard deviation for Y in all these plots (to 2dp);
  • Same correlation between X and Y (to 2dp).

But, we can see that these statistics are not enough to describe the patterns in the data. The scatterplots are still displaying completely different plots
